articles.title: Mike’s and Kevin’s Week in Tech: Streaming Music and Harassment in Venture Capital
articles.content: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Farhad is off this week, so Kevin Roose, a Times business columnist, filled in.

articles.title: Manhattan Prosecutor Joins Inquiry Into Russian Meddling in Election
articles.content: One federal prosecutor in Manhattan is being promoted to become the new chief of the public corruption unit, while another is departing to join Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel overseeing the investigation into Russia’s meddling in the 2016 presidential election.

articles.title: ‘Morning Joe’ Row Is Fresh Sign of TV’s Iron Grip on Trump
articles.content: There are a lot of insights to be drawn from the latest media maelstrom involving President Trump: about his sensitivity to criticism, his impulsivity, the way he talks about women and the ease with which he can still hurl the basest of insults.

articles.title: Airlines Face New Security Rules in Summer Scramble
articles.content: New directives from the Department of Homeland Security require airlines that fly to the United States to step up screening of passengers for trace amounts of explosives and, in some cases, impose more stringent security checks.

articles.title: U.S. to Allow Laptops Aboard Etihad Flights After Airline Tightens Security
articles.content: WASHINGTON — American officials on Sunday exempted Etihad Airways from a ban on laptops and other types of electronics on some flights bound for the United States, restrictions instituted in March because of concerns that the Islamic State was developing a bomb that could be hidden in portable devices.

articles.title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of July 3
articles.content: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills.

articles.title: Pinterest Wants to Show Advertisers It Can Run With the Big Dogs
articles.content: At the recent advertising conference in Cannes, France, Pinterest announced its presence with zeal and whimsy.

articles.title: French Energy Giant to Invest $1 Billion on Iran Gas Field
articles.content: TEHRAN — The French energy giant Total has agreed to invest $1 billion in Iran to develop a huge offshore gas field, Iranian news media reported on Sunday.

articles.title: The South Park Commons Fills a Hole in the Tech Landscape
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Ruchi Sanghvi was the first female engineer at Facebook, where she helped create the news feed that now serves as the primary window into the world’s largest social network. Then she built a start-up of her own and sold it to another rising Silicon Valley company, Dropbox, becoming one of its first female executives. But as she left Dropbox in 2014, she didn’t know what she would do next.

articles.title: Trump Tweets a Video of Him Wrestling ‘CNN’ to the Ground
articles.content: President Trump posted a short video to his Twitter account on Sunday in which he is portrayed wrestling and punching a figure whose head has been replaced by the logo for CNN.

articles.title: Hackers Find ‘Ideal Testing Ground’ for Attacks: Developing Countries
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — The attack had the hallmarks of something researchers had dreaded for years: malicious software using artificial intelligence that could lead to a new digital arms race in which A.I.-driven defenses battled A.I.-driven offenses while humans watched from the sidelines.

articles.title: After Ransomware Attack, Windows XP Is Not Back From the Dead
articles.content: Q. With the recent ransomware attacks, I was wondering if Microsoft will once again have security updates for Windows XP. There are millions of people who are still using XP, and it is one way hackers can use to infect newer computers, especially if XP is no longer secure.

articles.title: Daily Report: The Testing Labs of Malware
articles.content: When hackers stole $81 million from a bank in Bangladesh last year, fingers were eventually pointed at North Korea. The accusation indicated that North Korea’s hackers appeared willing to go after targets — a bank in a developing economy hardly considered a big player in international politics — not normally associated with nation-state cyberattacks.

articles.title: Former Barclays Executives Appear in Court Over Qatar Deal
articles.content: LONDON — A group of former Barclays executives appeared in a London court on Monday to answer charges that they conspired to misrepresent arrangements made with the Persian Gulf nation of Qatar in 2008, as the bank raised capital to help it weather the financial crisis.

articles.title: Independent Press Is Under Siege as Freedom Rings
articles.content: Happy Birthday, America, I guess.

articles.title: Harassment in the Tech Industry: Voices Grow on Social Media
articles.content: The New York Times recently spoke with more than two dozen women in the technology start-up industry about sexual harassment, provoking a range of reactions with their accounts.

articles.title: Did You Pack Too Much? Your Suitcase Knows

articles.title: When Just Vanilla Won’t Do, How About a Blueberry Pie Oreo?

articles.title: Travel Agents? No. Travel ‘Designers’ Create Strategies, Not Trips.

And that goes double for under the water. “A submarine observational thing to go down and look at coral reefs would never work for me,” said Mr. Straw, 74, an owner of the Santé Center for Healing, an inpatient treatment program in Argyle, Tex., for drug and alcohol addiction and eating disorders.

articles.title: Q. and A.: If Workers Are Scarce, Is It the Work or the Wages?

articles.title: Teamsters Union Tries to Slow Self-Driving Truck Push
articles.content: The Teamsters are throwing a wrench into the works of the self-driving movement.

articles.title: Walmart Apologizes for Sign Advertising Guns as Back-to-School Item
articles.content: Walmart officials are apologizing after a photograph surfaced online of a company sign that appeared to promote guns as essential back-to-school purchases.

articles.title: Wall Street’s Patience With Retailers’ Turnaround Efforts Runs Thin
articles.content: The last time Macy’s increased its sales, Donald J. Trump had not started running for president and the Chicago Cubs still had not won a World Series in more than a century.

articles.title: Author of HuffPost Article Fights Possible Defamation Suit by Fox News Host
articles.content: The author of a HuffPost article that prompted the suspension of the Fox News host Eric Bolling is fighting back against a possible $50 million defamation suit by Mr. Bolling.

articles.title: Jeffrey Lord, Trump Defender on CNN, Is Fired for Using Nazi Slogan
articles.content: Jeffrey Lord, the indefatigable defender of President Trump whose advocacy turned him into an unlikely political celebrity, was fired by CNN on Thursday after a convoluted Twitter exchange in which he evoked — mockingly, he said — a Nazi salute.

articles.title: Mike’s and Katie’s Week in Tech: Uber Infighting and the Google Memo
articles.content: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Farhad is off this week, so Katie Benner, a Times technology reporter, filled in.

articles.title: A Crisis Forces Google to Uphold Its Values While Fostering Debate
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — As a crisis unfurled at Google over an employee memo that argued biological factors helped explain the shortage of female engineers and leaders in Silicon Valley, some of the most pointed critiques of the company’s handing of the issue were posted to its own message boards.

articles.title: For Doomsday Preppers, the End of the World Is Good for Business
articles.content: Shoppers are buying six-month food supplies wrapped in military-grade Mylar pouches, and kits filled with duct tape, food bars and an air-filtration mask.

articles.title: Another Silicon Valley Start-Up Faces Sexual Harassment Claims
articles.content: Social Finance, a hot financial start-up, is the latest prominent Silicon Valley company to face accusations that it turned a blind eye to sexual harassment.

articles.title: A Quirky Flavored-Water Brand Tries to Grow Up
articles.content: After the studied zaniness of a campaign with the tag line “None of this makes sense” — a reference to how a five-calorie antioxidant drink could still manage to taste good — Bai Brands is looking to cast itself in a mature, inspirational image.

articles.title: Trade Commission Will Hear Solar Tariff Case, and Nafta Talks Begin
articles.content: Here’s a look at what’s coming up this week.

articles.title: EBay’s Founder Has a New Idea: Build a Dairy in Hawaii
articles.content: KAUAI, Hawaii — If Pierre Omidyar gets his way, 699 dairy cows will soon enjoy a glorious view of the Pacific Ocean, framed by a pristine beach.

articles.title: The Messy, Confusing Future of TV? It’s Here
articles.content: If you’re like me and the millions of other Americans who have canceled a cable television subscription over the past few years, you’re probably familiar with the phenomenon I’ve started calling “the hunt.”

articles.title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Aug. 14
articles.content: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

articles.title: Teaching A.I. Systems to Behave Themselves
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — At OpenAI, the artificial intelligence lab founded by Tesla’s chief executive, Elon Musk, machines are teaching themselves to behave like humans. But sometimes, this goes wrong.

articles.title: Uber Board Considers 3 Investment Offers to Buy Company’s Shares
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Uber’s board has voted to move forward on proposals by two investment groups to buy shares in the ride-hailing service and is considering a third offer, with any final decision set to affect who gains the upper hand at the company.

articles.title: Pandora, After Shake-Up, Picks New C.E.O.
articles.content: Pandora Media, the struggling internet radio giant, appointed a new chief executive on Monday, after a shake-up in June that installed SiriusXM as an influential new investor.

articles.title: GoDaddy Severs Ties With Daily Stormer After Charlottesville Article
articles.content: GoDaddy Inc., the web hosting company, severed ties with The Daily Stormer, a neo-Nazi and white supremacy website, after the site posted an article mocking Heather D. Heyer, the 32-year-old woman who was killed when a man drove into a crowd during a rally of white nationalists in Charlottesville, Va., on Saturday.

articles.title: Deal for Dickies Is a Bet on Trump’s Agenda
articles.content: If President Trump lives up to his slogan of making America great again, there will be many more workers in factories, mines and the like. And they will need clothing, durable threads that are not necessarily fashionable.

articles.title: C.E.O.s React After Trump Attacks Merck Chief
articles.content: Kenneth C. Frazier, chief executive of Merck, the pharmaceuticals company, on Monday resigned from President Trump’s American Manufacturing Council after the president failed to directly condemn the white nationalist protesters at the center of violent protests in Charlottesville, Va., over the weekend.

articles.title: Cracking the Airlines’ Dress Code
articles.content: It may matter what air travelers wear on the plane.

articles.title: Israeli Billionaire Beny Steinmetz Detained in Investigation
articles.content: The billionaire Beny Steinmetz was detained by the Israeli police on Monday morning for questioning in connection with an investigation into money laundering, obstruction of justice and bribery, officials said.

articles.title: Japan’s Economy Grows Again, in Longest Streak in 11 Years
articles.content: TOKYO — Japan’s economy grew more strongly than expected in the second quarter, extending the longest streak of uninterrupted growth in 11 years, government data showed on Monday.

articles.title: Outraged in Private, Many C.E.O.s Fear the Wrath of the President
articles.content: At what point do the C.E.O.s of the largest companies in the United States tell President Trump that enough is enough?

articles.title: When You Need Creativity to Strike, Make Way and Gear Up
articles.content: I don’t know when it happened, but it seems like being a creative person has become a function of how you look, who you hang out with, or what kinds of books you read while drinking something warm in a coffee shop.

articles.title: Wells Fargo Shows Erosion of Corporate Accountability Under Trump
articles.content: There is an adage that “it’s better to ask forgiveness than it is to get permission.” In the world of corporate misconduct, it seems that there is even less need to beg forgiveness these days as the government scales back how much it will police companies that appear to have violated the law.

articles.title: The Business Leaders Who Were on Trump’s Advisory Councils
articles.content: There was a mass exodus of executives from presidential advisory councils as they opposed stances taken by President Trump.

articles.title: Producers of ‘The Walking Dead’ Sue AMC Over Share of Profits
articles.content: In a legal action that will be watched closely in Hollywood, several producers of “The Walking Dead” on Monday sued AMC — the cable network that presents the hit TV series — seeking a greater share of profits.

articles.title: Solar Developers and Panel Makers Clash Over Tariff Request
articles.content: WASHINGTON — Dozens of solar industry executives, government officials and foreign diplomats gathered here on Tuesday to urge federal trade commissioners to reject a petition from two troubled domestic solar equipment manufacturers to impose steep tariffs and minimum price guarantees on similar imports.

articles.title: Uber Agrees to Privacy Audits in Settlement With F.T.C.
articles.content: WASHINGTON — Uber has agreed to two decades of privacy and security audits to settle federal accusations that it did not keep promises to protect customer data.

articles.title: Morning Agenda: Tallying the C.E.O. Desertion of Trump
articles.content: By late Monday, in the immediate aftermath of the violence in Charlottesville, Va., the number of corporate chiefs serving as advisers to President Trump had shrunk by three. The question is, will more follow?

articles.title: Wells Fargo Vice Chairwoman to Succeed Departing Chairman
articles.content: After a turbulent and scandal-filled year at Wells Fargo, the bank’s chairman is headed for the exit.

articles.title: One U.S. Factory Goes Global, While Trump Shrinks the World
articles.content: LEXINGTON, Ky. — Never mind the refrain that the American factory is supposedly a dinosaur in the age of globalization.

articles.title: U.S.C. Expands in a ‘Neglected’ Neighborhood, Promising Jobs and More
articles.content: LOS ANGELES — When the University of Southern California’s campus extension opens in South Los Angeles on Thursday, it will not just welcome 2,700 new college students. It will also be an ambitious test of a public-private partnership hoping to remake a historically underserved neighborhood.

articles.title: Walmart’s C.E.O. Joins Group to Rebuke Trump Over Charlottesville
articles.content: Walmart’s chief executive has issued a strong rebuke of President Trump’s response to the protests that turned violent in Charlottesville, Va., saying the president “missed a critical opportunity to help bring our country together.”

articles.title: This Was the Alt-Right’s Favorite Chat App. Then Came Charlottesville.
articles.content: They posted swastikas and praised Hitler in chat rooms with names like “National Socialist Army” and “Führer’s Gas Chamber.” They organized last weekend’s “Unite the Right” rally in Charlottesville, Va., connecting several major white supremacy groups for an intimidating display of force. And when that rally turned deadly, with the killing of a 32-year-old counterdemonstrator, they cheered and discussed holding a gathering at the woman’s funeral.

articles.title: China’s Online Giants Back $12 Billion Deal to Shake Up State Firm
articles.content: HONG KONG — Some of China’s biggest technology players are backing a plan to invest nearly $12 billion in one of the country’s telecommunications giants, the latest move in a broader government push to shake up the country’s bloated state-run companies.

articles.title: U.S. Begins Nafta Negotiations With Harsh Words
articles.content: WASHINGTON — The renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement is off to a rocky start.

articles.title: ‘Wow’: Stunned TV Hosts Reacted in Real Time to Trump
articles.content: “What I just saw gave me the wrong kind of chills,” a visibly stunned Chuck Todd said on MSNBC. “Honestly, I’m a bit shaken by what I just heard.”

articles.title: A Chinese Video Game Rakes In Cash — and Draws Young Rule Breakers
articles.content: SHANGHAI — In China, teenagers can purchase a fake ID online for as little as $2. Is it for buying booze? Subverting the state? Many simply want to play a game on their phones.

articles.title: Morning Agenda: Trump Bites Back Against C.E.O.s Who Rebuked Him
articles.content: President Trump campaigned in large part on his business background and with a pro-business stance.

articles.title: Akzo Nobel Ends Feud With Elliott Management
articles.content: LONDON — Akzo Nobel, the Dutch paint and chemicals company, said on Wednesday that it had reached a truce with Elliott Management, ending a dispute that had been the latest example of an activist investor looking to reshape a major business.

articles.title: Inside the C.E.O. Rebellion Against Trump’s Advisory Councils
articles.content: On Tuesday, Indra Nooyi, the chief executive of PepsiCo, joined a call with other prominent corporate chieftains who — like her — had agreed to advise President Trump.

articles.title: The Three Hour Commute to San Francisco
articles.content: The Three Hour Commute to San Francisco

articles.title: Getting Microsoft Word to Call You by Your Real Name
articles.content: Q. To activate Microsoft Word on my new laptop, I had to open a Microsoft account, but I didn’t use my real name. Now, when I edit a document in Word and add a comment, it lists the note under that made-up name. Any way I can get it to switch back to my real name?

articles.title: A Fox News Host Attacks Trump, and Some Viewers Bristle
articles.content: Fox News, television’s equivalent of a presidential safe space, kept up its steadfast defense of President Trump even as he faced an uproar this week over his response to the violence at a white supremacist rally in Virginia last Saturday. Anchors like Sean Hannity and Tucker Carlson praised the president and lauded his bare-knuckle criticism of the news media.

articles.title: Walmart’s C.E.O. Had Plenty to Say About Trump. So Did His Customers.
articles.content: Every week, 140 million Americans shop at 4,692 Walmart stores in 50 states. There is arguably no other company in the United States that so tangibly touches more Americans of every political, racial and cultural stripe.

articles.title: A 2:15 Alarm, 2 Trains and a Bus Get Her to Work by 7 A.M.
articles.content: STOCKTON, Calif. — Sheila James starts her Monday, and the workweek, at 2:15 a.m. This might be normal for a baker or a morning radio host, but Ms. James is a standard American office worker.

articles.title: White-Power Rock Bands Find Platform Online to Incite Hatred
articles.content: A deadly crime is committed by a white supremacist, and the ensuing media coverage draws attention to a dark corner of the music world: white-power rock bands, whose songs are widely available online and are often used as recruiting tools for extremist groups.

articles.title: Hackers Briefly Take Over HBO Twitter Accounts
articles.content: Several of HBO’s Twitter accounts were hacked late Wednesday night, raising further security concerns at a moment when the premium cable channel has been dealing with the sustained leaking of proprietary information.

articles.title: The World’s Biggest Tech Companies Are No Longer Just American
articles.content: HONG KONG — The technology world’s $400 billion-and-up club — long a group of exclusively American names like Apple, Google, Facebook, Microsoft and Amazon — needs to make room for two Chinese members.

articles.title: C.E.O.s Long Avoided Politics. Trump Is Changing the Calculus.
articles.content: The bar for a chief executive of a public corporation to repudiate a United States president is extraordinarily high. Corporate leaders aren’t given their power, prestige, responsibility and nine-figure pay packages to use the corner office as their personal soapbox.

articles.title: The Internal Combustion Engine Is Not Dead Yet
articles.content: Among all the world’s uncertainties, at least one matter seems settled: Batteries and electric motors will have a major role in powering the cars and trucks of our future. What is far less certain is how large that role will be, or how quickly the shift to electrification will happen.

articles.title: Morning Agenda: Debating Gary Cohn’s Future in Washington
articles.content: The business elite has deserted President Trump’s advisory panels in drastic fashion. Now many of them are wondering whether Gary D. Cohn, the White House official whom they see as their man in the administration, will also jump ship.

articles.title: Creating PDF Files on Your Phone
articles.content: Q. I know it’s possible to make PDF files with my phone’s camera and a scanner app, but is it possible to make PDF files out of documents already on my phone, like email threads and web pages so I can save them in cloud-based research folders?

articles.title: In Battle Over Texas Utility, Elliott Is Grasping at Straws
articles.content: Elliott Management, the hedge fund run by Paul Singer, is grasping at straws in its battle for bankrupt Energy Future Holdings.

articles.title: Where Is the Line? Charlottesville Forces Media and Tech Companies to Decide

articles.title: Dutch Utility Bets Its Future on an Unusual Strategy: Selling Less Power

articles.title: What Happens to Solar Power in an Eclipse? We’ll Find Out Monday
articles.content: Unlike most eclipse-watchers in the United States, Eric Schmitt wouldn’t mind seeing a few clouds in the sky when the moon starts blotting out the sun on Monday.

articles.title: Judge Says Waymo Can Tell Jurors That Uber Withheld Evidence
articles.content: In a strongly worded ruling on Thursday, a federal judge presiding over an intellectual property fight between Uber and Waymo, the self-driving car unit spun out of Google, said jurors in a coming trial may be told that Uber has been withholding key evidence.

articles.title: Squabbles Over the Family Summer Home? Don’t Hire a Lawyer Just Yet

articles.title: Carl Icahn Quits as a Special Adviser to President Trump
articles.content: Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire investor, is no longer advising President Trump on regulatory matters.

articles.title: Infosys Chief Quits After Battle With Founders
articles.content: NEW DELHI — India Inc. suffered a new blow on Friday when the chief executive of one of the country’s leading technology outsourcing companies suddenly resigned, a surprise move he attributed to “a continuous drumbeat of distractions and negativity.”

articles.title: Steve Bannon, Back on the Outside, Prepares His Enemies List
articles.content: Stephen K. Bannon has always been more comfortable when he was trying to tear down institutions — not work inside them.

articles.title: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: Apple’s Big Media Bet and More Uber Drama

articles.title: James Murdoch’s Rebuke of Trump May Signal a Shift
articles.content: At 5:55 p.m. on Thursday, James Murdoch sent an email to a list of blind-copied recipients offering a striking repudiation of President Trump and a pledge to donate $1 million to the Anti-Defamation League. He addressed the note to “friends,” stating in the first line that he was writing it in a “personal capacity, as a concerned citizen and a father.”

articles.title: The Benefits of Standing by the President
articles.content: He heaped praise on Jared Kushner at a private gathering of bankers and corporate executives in December, congratulating President Trump’s son-in-law on the surprise election triumph.

articles.title: To Sue Founder of Daily Stormer, a Neo-Nazi Site, First He Must Be Found
articles.content: For the past five months, a group of litigants has been trying to hold Andrew Anglin, the founder of the neo-Nazi website The Daily Stormer, to account for some of his actions. It has not been easy.

articles.title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Aug. 21
articles.content: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

articles.title: Tarnished by Charlottesville, Tiki Torch Company Tries to Move On
articles.content: As the images streamed out of Charlottesville, Va., this month showing white nationalists protesting the removal of a statue of Robert E. Lee, many could not help noticing the product illuminating the faces twisted into sneers of hate: Tiki torches.

articles.title: Total to Buy Maersk’s Oil and Gas Business for $4.95 Billion

articles.title: Great Wall Motor of China Sets Its Sights on Jeep
articles.content: China is trying to clamp down on overseas acquisitions by its companies. Hostility is growing in the United States toward Chinese deals. And the auto industry faces substantial change in the form of battery-powered vehicles and autonomous cars.

articles.title: Lender to Foreign Students Raises $40 Million in Financing
articles.content: As American universities’ interest in courting international students intensifies, an online lender that caters to them has drawn significant new financing.

articles.title: Identity Thieves Hijack Cellphone Accounts to Go After Virtual Currency
articles.content: Hackers have discovered that one of the most central elements of online security — the mobile phone number — is also one of the easiest to steal.

articles.title: Sempra Bid Tops Buffett and Singer in Race for Energy Future
articles.content: A month and a half ago, Warren E. Buffett unveiled a $9 billion takeover bid for Energy Future Holdings, setting up a battle with a fellow billionaire, Paul E. Singer, over the bankrupt Texas utility operator.

articles.title: Insider Trading Case to Be a Test of the Role of Friendship
articles.content: Inside information is like a child’s allowance, burning a hole in the pocket of the recipient who just has to pass it along to others. But not everyone who gets a tip about an impending deal violates the law. There is a fuzzy line between innocent trades and securities violations.

articles.title: Airports (Like Carriers) Use Twitter to Ease Travelers’ Concerns
articles.content: Before arriving at Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport, Joe Carella, the assistant dean of executive education at the Eller College of Management at the University of Arizona’s Phoenix campus, checks the airport’s Facebook page.

articles.title: Expanding the Windows Start Menu
articles.content: Q. In Windows 10, is it possible to get the screen where the apps are displayed as they were in Windows 8?

articles.title: Audi Engineer Implicates Superiors in Diesel Case, Lawyer Says

articles.title: Why Jeep Ought to Be for Keeps
articles.content: Selling Jeep would leave Sergio Marchionne nowhere to hide.

articles.title: Bumpy Times in Brazil, but Hedge Funds Boom
articles.content: RIO DE JANEIRO — After more than a decade as an asset manager for large multinational banks, a Brazilian, Márcio Appel, wanted to make it on his own. The political and economic upheaval in his country was not going to deter him.

articles.title: New Balance Wins $1.5 Million in Landmark China Trademark Case
articles.content: BEIJING — A Chinese court has ruled that three domestic shoemakers must pay New Balance $1.5 million in damages and legal costs for infringing the American sportswear company’s signature slanting “N” logo, in what lawyers said was the largest trademark infringement award ever granted to a foreign business in China.

articles.title: Morning Agenda: Betting Against Trump, or Staying to Help?
articles.content: Ray Dalio, the founder of the Bridgewater hedge fund company, is cutting his exposure to risk because of his concerns about stability in Washington.

articles.title: ‘Just Use the China’ or ‘Call 1-800-Got-Junk’: Readers on Inheriting Keepsakes
articles.content: As the American population ages, and older adults downsize into retirement communities or assisted-living facilities, the question arises: What do we do with all our stuff?

articles.title: Tunneling Though the Internet on Vacation
articles.content: Q. What do you think about virtual private networks? Do they really work to keep your information secure? I’m going on vacation to Alaska and I bought a VPN package, but I’m still not sure if it’s O.K. for me to check my bank account or use the Wi-Fi in Starbucks.

articles.title: Business Groups Court White House Even After C.E.O. Defections
articles.content: Last Wednesday, even as top executives were abandoning President Trump’s business advisory councils after his remarks on white supremacist violence in Charlottesville, Va., other industry leaders were busy making their interests known to a business-friendly White House.

articles.title: Apple Scales Back Its Ambitions for a Self-Driving Car
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — As new employees were brought into Apple’s secret effort to create a self-driving car a few years ago, managers told them that they were working on the company’s next big thing: A product that would take on Detroit and disrupt the automobile industry.

articles.title: Labor Wants to Make Nafta Its Friend. Here’s the Problem.
articles.content: Can Nafta be re-engineered to raise workers’ wages?

articles.title: Bayer-Monsanto Deal Faces Deeper Scrutiny in Europe
articles.content: LONDON — European antitrust regulators opened an in-depth investigation on Tuesday into Bayer’s $56 billion deal for Monsanto, a transaction that would create the world’s largest integrated pesticides and seeds company.

articles.title: Why Leasing a Smartphone May Be Better Than Buying One
articles.content: The Wirecutter, The New York Times site for product evaluations, has lots of advice on the best gadgets, but also has ideas on how to buy them in a smarter way. I talked to Andrew Cunningham, lead editor there, about how he thinks we should “buy” a cellphone: by leasing it.

articles.title: Dear iPhone: Here’s Why We’re Still Together After 10 Years
articles.content: Dear iPhone: It’s hard to believe we’re still together after 10 years, which is eons in the tech industry.

articles.title: A Hunt for Ways to Combat Online Radicalization
articles.content: Law enforcement officials, technology companies and lawmakers have long tried to limit what they call the “radicalization” of young people over the internet.

articles.title: Student Loan Company Accused of Mismanaging Debt Forgiveness Program
articles.content: One of the country’s largest servicers of federal student loans has badly mismanaged debt forgiveness programs for public service workers, significantly raising repayment costs for hundreds of thousands of borrowers, according to a lawsuit filed on Wednesday by the attorney general of Massachusetts.

articles.title: Wall Street Journal Editor Admonishes Reporters Over Trump Coverage
articles.content: Gerard Baker, the editor in chief of The Wall Street Journal, has faced unease and frustration in his newsroom over his stewardship of the newspaper’s coverage of President Trump, which some journalists there say has lacked toughness and verve.

articles.title: Hidden Banksy Art to Be Displayed by London Developer
articles.content: LONDON — It is not unusual for works of art to be lost and then found. It is rarer when the piece is painted on the side of a building.

articles.title: Morning Agenda: Fiat Chrysler’s Quest for a Chinese Partner
articles.content: The emergence of Great Wall Motors as a potential partner for Jeep highlights just how much Fiat Chrysler, Jeep’s owner, has looked to China to help bolster its fortunes.

articles.title: Samsung Takes Extra Safety Steps With New Galaxy Note Smartphone
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — The Galaxy Note 7 met an untimely demise last year after dozens of the Samsung phones overheated or exploded. So Samsung has taken extra steps to make sure the Note 7’s successor does not suffer the same outcome.

articles.title: Recognizing (and Rebelling Against) Robocalls
articles.content: Q. I get several phone calls each day on my cellphone from different phone numbers that I do not recognize. If I don’t answer, no message is left. If I answer, there is no response, just a hang-up. If I call the number back, there may be a voice message that “this number does not accept incoming calls” or that “all lines are busy,” or no response at all. What are these calls, and how should I respond? I have decided not to answer calls from unrecognized numbers, thinking that if it is important, the caller will leave a message. Problem with that is, I may miss an important call from someone not in my contacts list.

articles.title: Fiat Chrysler Is at a Crossroads. It’s Looking to China for a Solution.
articles.content: DETROIT — The event scheduled for Thursday at Fiat Chrysler’s Illinois assembly plant was supposed to shine a light on what the company does best: build high-margin Jeep sport utility vehicles.

articles.title: Knowing Where to Look 10 Years After Start of Financial Crisis
articles.content: Just five minutes before Monday’s solar eclipse, hundreds of beachgoers along Cape Cod National Seashore were donning special glasses and positioning empty cereal boxes with pinholes in them, tittering with anticipation to see the moon begin to blot out much of the sun. As a result, they missed something far more exciting some 10 yards offshore.

articles.title: As Coding Boot Camps Close, the Field Faces a Reality Check
articles.content: In the last five years, dozens of schools have popped up offering an unusual promise: Even humanities graduates can learn how to code in a few months and join the high-paying digital economy. Students and their hopeful parents shelled out as much as $26,000 seeking to jump-start a career.

articles.title: To Get People in Stores, Disney Offers ‘Star Wars’ Treasure Hunt
articles.content: LOS ANGELES — Disney is billing a new entertainment experience as a free “treasure hunt” for “Star Wars” fans. With any luck, of course, Disney will be collecting the real loot.

articles.title: Service Union Plans Big Push to Turn Midwest Political Tide
articles.content: Challenging the Republican ascendance in states where labor once carried enormous sway, a prominent union plans to spend tens of millions of dollars during the 2018 campaign cycle to reverse the trend.

articles.title: Disney, Ditching Netflix, Grabs a New Key to the Kingdom
articles.content: Is content still king?

articles.title: SoftBank and Fund to Invest $4.4 Billion in WeWork
articles.content: As part of a multibillion-dollar investment spree over the past year, SoftBank of Japan has bet on companies as diverse as the graphics chip maker Nvidia, an artificial intelligence software maker and an indoor farming start-up.

articles.title: Trump Takes Aim at the Press, With a Flamethrower
articles.content: Every time you think President Trump’s anti-press rhetoric can’t get worse, he finds a way of surprising you and not surprising you all at the same time.

articles.title: Administration Scraps Local-Hiring Plan for Public Works
articles.content: The Trump administration is abandoning another Obama-era regulatory initiative, killing a plan to allow cities to set aside work for local residents on federally funded public works projects.

articles.title: Finding an Audio Assist on Your Smartphone
articles.content: Q. Are there any tips or apps for hearing-impaired people who use phones or tablets and won’t use hearing aids?

articles.title: After Charlottesville, Even Dating Apps Are Cracking Down on Hate
articles.content: The Silicon Valley companies that make money off social media and online services have started to enact strong measures against extremism, barring white nationalists, white supremacists, neo-Nazis and others who follow creeds they deem racist and hateful.

articles.title: Deal-Making Is Alive and Well, but the Market Is Changing
articles.content: The urge to merge is alive and well.

articles.title: Chinese National Arrested in Connection with U.S. Cyberattacks
articles.content: The Justice Department on Monday charged a 36-year-old Chinese national, Yu Pingan, with conspiring with two other Chinese nationals to hack the computer networks of three unnamed companies in the United States.

articles.title: DreamHost Ordered to Release Some Trump Protest Website Data to U.S.

articles.content: LONDON — Regulators in Guernsey and in Singapore have opened an inquiry into Standard Chartered over the transfer of about $1.4 billion by clients with links to the Indonesian military.

articles.title: How Hurricanes Skewed September’s Job Numbers
articles.content: The United States’ nearly seven-year streak of job growth came to an end in September, as employers cut 33,000 jobs. But don’t read too much into that decline — Hurricanes Harvey and Irma, which ravaged Texas and Florida, wreaked havoc on employment.

articles.title: California Treasurer Urges State Pension Funds to Drop Gun Sellers
articles.content: John Chiang, California’s treasurer, urged board members of the state’s pension funds on Friday to divest holdings of retailers that sell guns and ammunition around the country that are illegal in California, which has stricter gun laws than most states. The letter came in the wake of this week’s mass shooting in Las Vegas that left 59 dead and more than 500 wounded.

articles.title: Harvey Weinstein’s Media Enablers
articles.content: Now that The New York Times has put together a stomach-turning chronicle of alleged sexual harassment by the movie mogul Harvey Weinstein — complete with brave, on-the-record statements from, among others, the actress Ashley Judd — we’re hearing a lot about how the story of his misconduct was “the worst-kept secret” in Hollywood and New York.

articles.title: Why Aren’t Wages Rising Faster Now That Unemployment Is Lower?
articles.content: When labor markets tighten, wages are expected to rise. But in recent years, as unemployment has fallen below 5 percent in the United States, wages have not been increasing as fast as in the past. Economists debate the reasons; workers grapple with the consequences.

articles.title: Without Harvey Weinstein, Is There a Weinstein Company?
articles.content: LOS ANGELES — A bicoastal staff meeting of the Weinstein Company was hastily convened late Thursday. Staff members were scared and shaken after public complaints of sexual harassment against Harvey Weinstein, the entertainment company’s pugnacious co-founder. With the help of a video conferencing system, David Glasser, the Weinstein Company’s president and chief operating officer, tried to rally the troops.

articles.title: Hosting Proms and Selling Cows: North Korean Embassies Scrounge for Cash
articles.content: SOFIA, Bulgaria — While the embassies of most countries promote the interests of companies back home, North Korea’s are in business for themselves.

articles.title: Lisa Bloom, Lawyer Advising Harvey Weinstein, Resigns Amid Criticism From Board Members
articles.content: The lawyer Lisa Bloom resigned on Saturday as an adviser to Harvey Weinstein, the high-powered film producer facing allegations of rampant sexual harassment, amid harsh criticism of her handling of his defense.

articles.title: Germany’s Shift to Green Power Stalls, Despite Huge Investments
articles.content: BETZIGAU, Germany — Katharina Zinnecker’s farm in the foothills of the German Alps has been in the family since 1699. But to squeeze a living from it today, she and her husband need to do more than sell the milk from their herd of cows.

articles.title: Anti-Semitism’s Rise Gives The Forward New Resolve
articles.content: The Forward has chronicled the experiences of Jews in the United States for 120 years. Initially published as a Yiddish-language lifeline for those who fled hatred and strife in Europe, in recent years it had to work harder to stay relevant to a community now largely assimilated, finding new stories to tell about transgender rabbis, the challenges of interfaith marriage and even the “secret Jewish history of The Who.”

articles.title: The Economy Is Humming. Bankers Are Cheering. What Could Go Wrong?
articles.content: For decades, the global economy has been defined by dissonance.

articles.title: Disney’s Big Bet on Streaming Relies on Little-Known Tech Company
articles.content: For two days in late June, Disney’s board of directors gathered at Walt Disney World in Florida to wrestle with one topic: how technology was disrupting the company’s traditional movie, television and theme park businesses, and what to do about it?

articles.title: McGruff the Crime Dog, Outliving His Creator, Fights On
articles.content: Jack Keil had the slogan first. He wrote six words — “Take a bite out of crime” — on the back of an envelope in a Kansas City airport lounge.

articles.title: Harvey Weinstein Is the (Whispered) Talk of Hollywood
articles.content: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Movie potentates were peppered across the Tower Bar here as usual on Friday night. Over in one dimly lit corner sat a martini-drinking movie star and his manager. And the restaurant’s lively owner, Jeff Klein, worked the room as he normally does, pausing to schmooze here and shake an important hand there.

articles.title: An Epic, and Costly, Boardroom Battle at Procter & Gamble
articles.content: Corporate board elections are usually dull affairs best left to investor newsletters and government filings.

articles.title: Deep in Trump Country, a Big Stake in Health Care
articles.content: In an Arkansas community where medical care is the main job engine, the persistent cloud over the Affordable Care Act has left residents uneasy.

articles.title: China Hastens the World Toward an Electric-Car Future
articles.content: SHENZHEN, China — There is a powerful reason that automakers worldwide are speeding up their efforts to develop electric vehicles — and that reason is China.

articles.title: Leaving Flickr? How to Preserve Your Online Photo Albums
articles.content: Q. I’m deleting Yahoo and my Flickr account. In regards to Flickr, I still have most of the original images on my computer, but need to retrieve a handful of photos I can’t find on my hard drive. Can I download the Flickr copies in the original resolution, or will they be in a lower image quality?

articles.title: For Disney’s Iger, an Unlikely Political Turn
articles.content: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Before the Trump presidency, who could have imagined that the Walt Disney Company would find itself at the fiery center of the American political debate?

articles.title: Corker Takes On Trump, Hedge Funds Lose on Puerto Rico: DealBook Briefing
articles.content: When a senator says that President Trump is making threats that could set the United States “on the path to World War III” — as Senator Bob Corker told the NYT on Sunday — you might expect the entire business community to take notice.

articles.title: Las Vegas Massacre Gives InfoWars More Conspiracy Fodder
articles.content: The mystery of why Stephen Paddock smuggled an arsenal into a Las Vegas hotel room before firing into a crowd of concertgoers, killing dozens and injuring hundreds, has only deepened in the days since the massacre. His motives remain elusive, his beliefs unclear.

articles.title: Nobel in Economics Announced, and Bank Earnings Begin
articles.content: ECONOMY

articles.title: Weinstein Company Joins Ranks of Firms With Bosses Who Misbehave
articles.content: There’s no such thing as a founder who goes quietly. The Weinstein Company, the film studio that fired one of its two co-founder brothers amid sexual harassment allegations, now joins other companies, like Fox News and Uber, that parted ways with influential bosses who misbehaved or stood idly by while others did. There’s dual risk, both from what the departing founder takes away and what he leaves behind.

articles.title: Nobel in Economics Is Awarded to Richard Thaler
articles.content: WASHINGTON — Richard H. Thaler, whose work has persuaded many economists to pay more attention to human behavior, and many governments to pay more attention to economics, was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences on Monday.

articles.title: G.M. Acquires Strobe, Start-Up Focused on Driverless Technology
articles.content: DETROIT — General Motors said on Monday that it had acquired a company that specializes in laser-imaging technology geared toward enhancing the development of autonomous vehicles.

articles.title: Deposed Hedge Fund Kingpin Steven Cohen Loses His Top Trader
articles.content: The longtime top trader for Steven A. Cohen, the deposed hedge fund kingpin, is leaving — just months before Mr. Cohen is expected to re-enter the hedge fund game.

articles.title: Apple Joins Forces With Steven Spielberg’s Amblin Television
articles.content: Apple is digging into the more than $1 billion it has set aside for original programming to create its first known television project: a revival of a Steven Spielberg series from the 1980s.

articles.title: Masayoshi Son’s Grand Plan for SoftBank’s $100 Billion Vision Fund
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — When Eric Gundersen, the chief executive of a mapping start-up called Mapbox, met Masayoshi Son, the head of the Japanese conglomerate SoftBank, in late July, he expected to have to sell Mr. Son on what made Mapbox important.

articles.title: Start-Up Bets on Tech Talent Pipeline From Africa
articles.content: When Tolulope Komolafe first heard the pitch, she was skeptical. A fledgling company in Lagos, Nigeria, would pay her to learn how to write modern computer code and then offer her a good job in the high-tech economy.

articles.title: HelloFresh, the Meal Delivery Service, Pursues I.P.O. in Frankfurt
articles.content: LONDON — HelloFresh, the German meal delivery company, said on Tuesday that it planned to raise up to $352 million in an initial public offering in Frankfurt.

articles.title: Glaxo Could Make a Nice Home for Pfizer’s Consumer Division
articles.content: Painkillers and hemorrhoid cream: These are either the recipe for a terrible night in, or a potentially good corporate deal.

articles.title: Why Big Cities Thrive, and Smaller Ones Are Being Left Behind

articles.title: Pfizer Considers Spinning Off or Selling Consumer Health Unit
articles.content: The pharmaceutical giant Pfizer said on Tuesday that it had begun a strategic review of its consumer health care division that could result in the unit, whose products include Advil, Centrum supplements and ChapStick, being spun off or sold.

articles.title: BAE Systems to Cut Almost 2,000 Jobs in Britain

articles.title: Disney, Hillary Clinton and the Obamas Condemn Weinstein

articles.title: China to Debtors: Pay Up or Be Shamed

articles.title: Turkey Convicts Wall Street Journal Reporter in Absentia
articles.content: A Turkish court convicted a longtime Wall Street Journal reporter in absentia on terrorism charges and sentenced her to two years and one month in prison.

articles.title: BlackRock, the World’s Biggest Money Manager, Expands Again

articles.content: But even if Procter & Gamble beats Nelson Peltz — something the activist investor insists won’t happen — how much of a victory would it really be?

articles.title: As ‘Unicorns’ Emerge, Utah Makes a Case for Tech Entrepreneurs
articles.content: When Josh James traveled to the Bay Area in 2000, seeking funding for a web analytics company he had founded, he spoke at length with a venture capitalist about his plans for growth. The conversation was going well, Mr. James recently recalled, until the investor asked where he was based. “As soon as I told him I was from Utah, he literally, without saying a word, turned around and walked away.”

articles.title: Japan Stocks Hit 21-Year High as Investors Shrug Off Concerns
articles.content: TOKYO — Japan still faces deep structural problems. Its population is aging and dwindling. China has stepped up its manufacturing game. Corporate stalwarts like Toshiba and Kobe Steel have stumbled.

articles.title: The Frightful Five Want to Rule Entertainment. They Are Hitting Limits.

articles.title: How Did NBC Miss Out on a Harvey Weinstein Exposé?
articles.content: When Ronan Farrow made a guest appearance on MSNBC’s “The Rachel Maddow Show” on Tuesday night, he tried to make it clear that he was the reporter, not the story.

articles.title: We Asked Facebook 12 Questions About the Election, and Got 5 Answers
articles.content: Nearly a year after Election Day, Facebook’s role in our modern political infrastructure is finally coming into focus.

articles.title: Sheryl Sandberg Blitzes Washington in P.R. Push for Facebook
articles.content: WASHINGTON — For months, Facebook has been trying to counter criticism about its influence on the 2016 presidential election. The company has hired three crisis communications firms and has bought digital and newspaper ads. Mark Zuckerberg, its chief executive, has posted live video to the social network to explain how much he cared about election integrity.

articles.title: Facing Down the Network That Protected Harvey Weinstein
articles.content: Because of the stories that have come out over the last week concerning the complaints about the movie mogul Harvey Weinstein, including two deeply reported New York Times investigative stories and an 8,000-word report from The New Yorker, readers now know all about his alleged pattern of sexual misconduct that victimized numerous women stretching back decades. And many of them are asking on social media why the story didn’t come out sooner.

articles.title: Lufthansa to Buy Units of Air Berlin for $249 Million
articles.content: LONDON — The German flag carrier Lufthansa signed an agreement on Thursday to buy sections of Air Berlin, a low-cost carrier that had filed for insolvency this summer.

articles.title: N.F.L. Players May Have an Ally in Their Protests: Labor Law
articles.content: As National Football League team owners consider President Trump’s call to fire players who refuse to stand for the national anthem, they have stumbled into one of the most consequential debates in today’s workplace: How far can workers go in banding together to address problems related to their employment?

articles.content: Breaking:

articles.title: Tax Cuts Could Boost U.S. Bank Stocks. But Other Issues Are More Pressing.
articles.content: Owners of Wall Street banks are being taken for a Washington ride. The S. & P. 500 Bank Index has surged 12 percent since Sept. 8. That is not justified by the trajectory of earnings, as JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup reported results Thursday that were no better than steady. Tax cuts would support higher stocks, but they’re at best some way off. In the meantime, banks have other concerns.

articles.title: Tech Giants, Once Seen as Saviors, Are Now Viewed as Threats
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — At the start of this decade, the Arab Spring blossomed with the help of social media. That is the sort of story the tech industry loves to tell about itself: It is bringing freedom, enlightenment and a better future for all mankind.

articles.title: 21st Century Fox Pressed by Investment Group to Overhaul Board
articles.content: An organization that advises several union pension funds invested in Rupert Murdoch’s 21st Century Fox called on Thursday for the company to overhaul its board and conduct a comprehensive review of its workplace culture in the wake of sexual and racial harassment scandals at its Fox News division.

articles.title: HSBC Names John Flint as Chief Executive
articles.content: LONDON — Mark Tucker is the first outsider to serve as HSBC’s chairman, but he has chosen someone from within as the bank’s next chief executive.

articles.title: Google Unveils Job Training Initiative With $1 Billion Pledge
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Google unveiled an initiative on Thursday to help train Americans for jobs in technology and committed to donating $1 billion over the next five years to nonprofits in education and professional training.

articles.title: China’s Embrace of Private Investment Is Getting Tighter
articles.content: China’s president, Xi Jinping, wants to regain the private sector’s confidence even as he squeezes it more tightly. Aligning private investment with state priorities could grease the bureaucratic skids for some companies, but more official meddling in boardrooms is unlikely to produce good business decisions. Opaque party politics will confuse outside investors and blur the line between some state and private companies.

articles.title: What Does Facebook Consider Hate Speech? Take Our Quiz

articles.title: Amazon Studios Chief Suspended After Sexual Harassment Claim

articles.title: How to Get Cortana to Keep Track of Your Favorite Teams
articles.content: Q. How do I make the Windows Cortana program on my PC collect news and scores for specific sports teams?

articles.title: Harvey Weinstein May Get Kicked Out of the Oscar Club
articles.content: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Ninety years ago, Louis B. Mayer created an elite club that would become the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Membership, granted for life, quickly turned into the ultimate indicator of status — moviedom’s equivalent of the mob’s “made man.”

articles.title: BASF to Buy Bayer Units for $7 Billion
articles.content: LONDON — The German chemicals giant Bayer said on Friday that it had agreed to sell parts of its crop science business to BASF for about $7 billion.

articles.title: Twitter Users Split on Boycott Over Platform’s Move Against Rose McGowan
articles.content: Activists, celebrities and journalists joined a boycott of Twitter on Friday to protest the social media platform’s locking of the account of the actress Rose McGowan, a fierce critic of the film producer Harvey Weinstein over his alleged sexual harassment and assaults of women.

articles.title: Facebook Goes to Washington: DealBook Briefing
articles.content: Will a public relations campaign in Washington by Facebook’s Sheryl Sandberg and others take the heat off technology giants?

articles.title: U.S. and Europe May Collide on Taxing Apple and Amazon

articles.title: G.M. and Union in Canada Reach Tentative Agreement to End Strike
articles.content: General Motors and Canada’s largest trade union have reached a tentative agreement in a labor dispute that has idled an Ontario plant that makes a popular sport utility vehicle, the Chevrolet Equinox.

articles.title: Harvey Weinstein Ousted From Motion Picture Academy
articles.content: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood’s de facto governing body, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, voted overwhelmingly on Saturday to “immediately expel” Harvey Weinstein, breaking with 90 years of precedent and turning one of the biggest Oscar players in history into a hall-of-fame pariah.

articles.title: Assessing Trump’s Criticisms of Iran and the Nuclear Deal
articles.content: President Trump declared his intention not to recertify the Iran nuclear deal in a forceful speech on Friday. But the rationale he provided includes several misleading or incomplete statements about the terms of the deal, what he considers a violation of the agreement and Iran itself. Here is an assessment.

articles.title: Tesla Fires Hundreds of Workers
articles.content: DETROIT — The electric-car maker Tesla fired hundreds of workers this week after a series of performance reviews conducted during the biggest expansion in the company’s history.

articles.title: Volkswagen Avoids Effort to Beef Up Oversight in German State Election
articles.content: FRANKFURT — Germany’s largest opposition party appeared likely to retain power in an important state election on Sunday that could sway the balance of power in Berlin and stymie efforts to strengthen oversight at Volkswagen, which dominates the region’s economy.

articles.title: As the World Tweets, Social Media Chiefs Remain Tight-Lipped
articles.content: If only Twitter, Facebook and Google could keep their stories straight.

articles.title: Buy a Sofa Online? Wayfair Is Counting on It

articles.title: Executive Mentors Wanted. Only Millennials Need Apply.

articles.title: Amazon Turns on the Charm Amid Criticism From Right and Left

In a Senate building, lawmakers and their aides attended policy panels on how Amazon manages privacy on its Echo devices and how sales for small businesses are booming on its online store.

articles.title: Fed’s Janet Yellen Says the Economy Remains in Good Health
articles.content: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen, chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, said on Sunday that the American economy was in good health in an upbeat assessment that reinforced expectations the Fed is planning to raise its benchmark interest rate later this year.

articles.title: Reeling From Scandal, Weinstein Company Gets a Financial Lifeline

But the fate of the studio, including whether its co-founder Bob Weinstein would stay involved, remained far from resolved.

articles.title: Are the Days of Low Oil Prices Receding?

articles.title: A Chilly Winter Forecast for Nordstrom and Other Retailers
articles.content: Retailers hoping to put themselves up for sale are in for a long winter. Take Nordstrom. With large insider stakes and growing revenue, the $6.7 billion department store chain was a prime candidate for a buyout. Now it is shelving its sale until after the holidays. It may be hoping for a higher price, but the delay suggests even risk-tolerant buyers are cool on the sector.

articles.title: Justices to Decide on Forcing Technology Firms to Provide Data Held Abroad
articles.content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to decide whether federal prosecutors can force technology companies to turn over data stored outside the United States.

articles.title: Nordstrom Suspends Effort to Go Private Until After the Holidays

articles.title: A Nafta Battleground on the Shores of Canada

But an American company’s scuttled plans to build a quarry here have turned these quiet fishing grounds into a case study of the kind of thorny disputes that threaten to derail the North American Free Trade Agreement.

articles.title: Deep in Trump Country, a Big Stake in Health Care
articles.content: Medical care is the job engine in an area that strongly backed President Trump, and the cloud over the Affordable Care Act has left residents uneasy.

articles.title: Where Internet Orders Mean Real Live Jobs, and New Life for Communities
articles.content: Vast warehouses are being built for packing orders, fueling a demand for lower-skilled workers and reviving areas that once relied on manufacturing.

articles.title: Moving the Windows 10 Taskbar by Hand

articles.title: Google Serves Fake News Ads in an Unlikely Place: Fact-Checking Sites

articles.title: Google’s Pixel 2 Smartphone Is a Powerful Extravagance
articles.content: The last smartphone I reviewed was the original Apple iPhone, which ushered in the mobile revolution back in 2007. At the time, I didn’t exactly give the device a rave. Two weeks after waiting in line for hours outside the San Francisco Apple Store and paying $540 for the iPhone, I even returned it and got my money back.

articles.title: Harvey Weinstein, Fired on Oct. 8, Resigns From Company’s Board
articles.content: LOS ANGELES — Following allegations of sexual harassment against Harvey Weinstein, the movie and television studio he helped to found swiftly fired him as an employee. On Tuesday, during a meeting convened to affirm that dismissal, Mr. Weinstein resigned from the Weinstein Company’s board.

articles.title: George Soros Transfers Billions to Open Society Foundations
articles.content: George Soros, the billionaire hedge fund manager and a major Democratic donor, has given $18 billion to his Open Society Foundations, one of the largest transfers of wealth ever made by a private donor to a single foundation.

articles.title: Why Investors Can’t Get Enough of Tajikistan’s Debt

articles.title: Top General’s Grief Becomes Political Talking Point for Trump

He made only a fleeting, oblique reference to his son Second Lt. Robert Kelly as he paid tribute to the two other fallen service members who held their ground for six seconds as a truck bore down on them.

articles.title: Senate Plan Gives Health Care Industry Hope, for Now: DealBook Briefing

articles.title: How Many People Watch Netflix? Nielsen Tries to Solve a Mystery

articles.title: A MacArthur ‘Genius’ on Overcoming Modern Farm Slavery

An organizer and human rights strategist, he co-founded the Coalition of Immokalee Workers, a group that pioneered a system for overcoming brutal conditions in American agriculture. Last week, the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation awarded Mr. Asbed one of 24 annual fellowships, known colloquially as a “genius grant,” to support his work in this area.

articles.title: American Express C.E.O. Ken Chenault to Step Down

articles.title: China’s Reform Hopefuls Watch for Names. Only One May Matter.
